title-group.article-title: Optimal control strategies of cell infections in a covid-19 model with inflammatory response

contrib-group.aff: aSchool of Mathematical and Statistical Science, North West University, 11 Hoffman Street, Potchefstroom 2351, South Africa
bDSI-NRF Centre of Excellence in Mathematical and Statistical Sciences (CoE-MaSS), South Africa
cLaboratoire de Modélisation, Mathématiques, Informatique, Applications et Simulation, Université de N’Djamena, P.O Box: 1027, Chad

license.license-p: Since January 2020 Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information in English and Mandarin on the novel coronavirus COVID-19. The COVID-19 resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier hereby grants permission to make all its COVID-19-related research that is available on the COVID-19 resource centre - including this research content - immediately available in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database with rights for unrestricted research re-use and analyses in any form or by any means with acknowledgement of the original source. These permissions are granted for free by Elsevier for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active.

abstract.p: In this work, we investigate the optimal strategies to limit cell infections and virus production at low cost in a mathematical virus model for Covid-19 with inflammatory response. We consider treatment and introduce two intervention control parameters: u1 for the drug therapy efficacy in preventing new infections, and u2 for the drug therapy efficacy in inhibiting viral production (with 0⩽u1,u2⩽1). We fully analyse the optimal control problem and establish the existence and uniqueness of the optimal solution. Moreover, we show that the optimal control is not only measurable, but is also continuous. Our numerical illustrations show how therapy can overturn a lethal infection state into a survivable stage, and vice versa.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since its appearance in 2019, the Coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) has orchestrated enormous loss and trauma worldwide. Caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-Cov-2 Virus), Covid-19 has been declared to be a pandemic on the 11th of March 2020 by the WHO. Symptoms includes cough, sneeze, fatigue, headache, shortness of breath, and loss of taste or smell. It can be manifested as an influenza-like illness with 89% fever, 68% cough, 38.8% muscle pain, 35% chest pain, or 4% kidney damage [Delafontaine [8]]. Though most cases are mild, about 20% of cases may lead to severe pathology such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or pneumonia.

Many mathematical models have been developed in an unprecedented short time-frame to predict different scenarios of non-pharmaceutical interventions [Atangana and Araz [2], Bachar et al. [4], Chen et al. [7], Giordano et al. [10], Chen et al. [6], Memon et al. [16], Musa et al. [20], Musa and Dahai [21], Parolini et al. [24], Tay et al. [30], Tchepmo Djomegni et al. [31]]. Their results have greatly contributed to epidemiological surveillance and informed decision-making policy on public health. Tchepmo, Djomegni et al. [31] proposed a quantitative approach to assess the impact of post-lockdown on the spread of the disease. Yang et al. [32], in their model, showed that the improvement of lymphonia and reduction of inflammation may represent effective therapeutic strategies for Covid-19 patients. Musa and Daihai [21] considered awareness programmes and hospitalisation strategies for mild and severe cases. They showed that raising awareness was the best strategy to mitigate the spread in Nigeria. Chen [6] considered a model bats-hosts-network-humans.

The main target of SARS-Cov-2 is the pulmonary alveoli. ARDS is caused by direct lung injury through viral infection, or over-stimulation of inflammation, leading to high intervention of pro-inflammatory mediators and immune responses to the virus [Guan et al. [11]]. Anti-inflammatory drugs can be used to alleviate inflammation. However, an improper calibration of the dosage and duration of the drugs may weaken the healing process from infection. Mathematical models have long been developed to study the immune response to lung infection [Baccam et al. [3], Handel [12], Ho et al. [13], Mochan et al. [18], Neumann [22], Nowak et al. [23], Perelson et al. [25], Price et al. [26], Saenz et al. [28]]. Unlike previous approaches, Mochan et al. [17] proposed a new model that emphasises on the importance of the inflammatory response to viral infection, using information from pro-inflammatory mediators to combat viral growth. It also captures the dynamics in the lower and upper respiratory tracts. Their model can be applied to asymptomatic infection, severe but survival infection, or lethal infection due to excess inflammation. They fit their model to SARS-Cov-2 experimental data from rhesus macaque infection as it has been proved to be similar to that in humans [Josset et al. [14], Munster et al. [19]]. They did not analyse the mathematical model, but rather, performed simulations to test the impact of some parameters on the dynamics of the infection. We will investigate the optimal control strategies to limit cell infection and virion production at low cost by introducing two intervention parameters. The existence, characterisation and uniqueness of the optimal solution of the control problem will be fully established.

sec.title: Optimal control model
sec.p:
We consider a Covid-19 infection model describing the interactions between epithelial cells, virus, and inflammatory responses. Experiments on macaques have shown that the virus can move from the lower respiratory tract (LRT) to the upper respiratory tract (URT), and infect epithelial cells [Munster et al. [19]]. The presence of infected epithelial cells will activate the pro-inflammatory process of the immune response, and inhibit the production of virions due to the presence of pro-inflammatory mediators (which reduce the ability of infected cells to release virions). Pro-inflammatory mediators can destroy epithelial cells and cause severe damage. We introduce two time-dependent intervention control parameters: u1 the drug therapy efficacy in preventing new infections, and u2 the drug therapy efficacy in inhibiting viral production (with 0⩽u1,u2⩽1). The fundamental principle from which the mathematical model is built is governed by the followings:▷
rate of change of virus (V) = virus production ± migration - deaths.▷
rate of change of healthy cells (H) = growth - infection - death due to inflammation.▷
rate of change of infected cells (I) = new infections - death (natural or due to inflammation).▷
rate of change of pro-inflammatory mediators (F) = production (proportional to density of infected cells) - degradation.▷
rate of change of anti-inflammatory mediators (G) = production (caused by the presence of pro-inflammatory mediators) - degradation.

The resulting mathematical model is given by(1)dVUdt=(1-u2)γVIU+βVL-(γVHHU+αVH+aVH)VU=g1 (2)dHUdt=bHD(Hmax-HU-IU)HU-(1-u1)γHVVUHU-aHFFHU=g2 (3)dIUdt=(1-u1)γHVVUHU-(aIFF+aI)IU=g3 (4)dVLdt=(1-u2)γVIL-βVL-(γVHHL+αVH+aVH)VL=g4 (5)dHLdt=bHD(Hmax-HL-IL)HL-(1-u1)γHVVLHL-aHFFHL=g5 (6)dILdt=(1-u1)γHVVLHL-(aIFF+aI)IL=g6 (7)dFdt=bFI(IU+IL)-aFF=g7 (8)dGdt=γFGF-aGG=g8,and the meaning of the variables and parameters are given in Table 1 . The term (1-u1)γHV represents the infection rate of epithelial cells in the presence of the drug, and (1-u2)γV is the production rate of virus under therapy.Table 1
Description of model parameters (1), (7).
VU/VLdensities of virus present in the URT/LRT
HU/HLdensities of healthy epithelial cells in the URT/LRT
IU/ILdensities of infected epithelial cells present in the URT/LRT
F/Gdensity of pro/anti-inflammatory mediators
γVvirus replication rate
γVHAbsorption rate of virus by epithelial cells
αVHrate of destruction of virus in the URT by adaptive immunity
aVHkilling rate of virus in the URT by non-specific immunity
βvirus migration rate from LRT to URT
bHDregeneration rate of healthy epithelial cells
aHFdamage rate of healthy cells by inflammation
aIFdamage rate of infected cells by inflammation
aIdeath rate of infected cells
γHVrate of infection of healthy cells by the virus
Hmaxmaximum capacity of epithelial cells in each airway
bFIrate of stimulation of inflammation by the presence of infected cells
aFinflammation decay rate
γFGrate of stimulation of anti-inflammatory signal by inflammation
aGrate of degradation of the anti-inflammatory mediator

The initial model was proposed by Mochan et al. [17] to reflect the experiment on macaques. They fitted the model to experimental data and investigated through numerical simulations, the impact of some parameters on the dynamics of the infections. When there is no control (u1=u2=0), we note that the basic reproduction number is R0=max(R1,R2), where R1 and R2 are basis reproduction numbers associated with the URT and LRT respectively, and given by(9)R1=γVγHVHmaxaI(γHVHmax+αVH+aVH),R2=γVγHVHmaxaI(γHVHmax+αVL+aVL+β).Thus, reducing the replication rate γV of the virus or the infection rate γHV of epithelial cells will reduce secondary infections (since ∂R0∂γV>0 and ∂R0∂γHV). The implementation of these strategies requires costs. We aim in this work to investigate the optimal strategy to reduce infections at low cost. We consider the objective function(10)J(u1,u2)=∫0T[a1IU(t)+a2VU(t)+a3IL(t)+a4VL(t)+12(A1u12(t)+A2u22(t))]dt,where a1,a2,a3,a4,A1 and A2 are non-negative constants. The linear terms in (10) represent infected cells and virus, and the quadratic terms in u1 and u2 represent the treatment cost and physiological cost respectively. Our optimal control problem consists of(11)min(u1,u2)∈UJ(u1,u2) subjectedtothestatesystem(1)-(7),where U={u=(u1,u2):[0,T]→[0,1]×[0,1]measurablefunctions}. We will investigate the existence and uniqueness of the solution for the control problem (11). We note that the Eq. (8) is decoupled and does not influence the system (1), (7). We assume the positivity and boundedness of the solutions of (1), (7).

statement.label: Theorem 1
statement.p: There exists an optimal control pair (u1∗,u2∗) for the problem (11).

statement.label: Proof
statement.p:
We show that the conditions in Fleming and Rishel [9] are satisfied.i.
The growth and Lipschitz conditions on the RHS of (1), (7) are trivially satisfied since g=(g1,…,g7)T is of class C1 in all the state variables x=(VU,HU,IU,VL,HL,IL,F)T, the superscript T denoting the transposing of a vector. By Cauchy-Peanot theorem [Simpson [29]], the set F={x(0)|u∈UisLebesgue-integralon[0,T]andthestatesystem(1)-(7)issatisfied} is not empty.ii.
By definition the set U is closed and convex.iii.
The function g is continuous in the control u=(u1,u2) and state variables, and linear in u with coefficients depending on time and state variables.iv.
The function(12)f(x,u)=a1IU+a2VU+a3IL+a4VL+12(A1u12+A2u22)is convex in u and verify(13)f(x,u)⩾12(A1u12+A2u22)⩾C1(u12+u22)-C2,where C1=12min(A1,A2) and C2>0.
Therefore, there exists a solution (u1∗,u2∗) for the control problem (11). □.

sec.title: Characterisation of the optimal control
sec.p:
To give a precise formulation of the optimal control u∗(t)=(u1∗(t),u2∗(t)) we use Pontragin’s Maximum Principle [27]. The Lagrangian (Hamiltonian + penalty) associated to the control problem is defined by(14)L=f(x,u)+<R,g(x,u)>-w11u1-w12(1-u1)-w21u2-w22(1-u2),where R=(λ1,…,λ7)T,<.,.> is the Euclidean scalar product and wi,j⩾0 for all i,j∈{1,2} and verifyw11u1=w12(1-u1)=0attheoptimalcontrolu1∗w21u2=w22(1-u2)=0attheoptimalcontrolu2∗.We note that the λi,i=1,…,7, are called adjoint variables, and wi,j (1⩽i,j⩽2) are penalty multipliers ensuring the boundedness between 0 and 1 of the control.Proposition 2
The optimal control (u1∗,u2∗) for the problem (11) is characterised by(15)u1∗=max0,min1,(λ3-λ2)γVHVUHU+(λ6-λ5)γVHVLHLA1 (16)u2∗=max0,min1,λ1γVIU+λ4γVILA2. Proof
From Pontragin’s Maximum Principle [Pontryagin et al. [27]], the optimal control (u1∗,u2∗) satisfies(17)∂L∂u1∗=∂L∂u2∗=0.Applying to (14), we get(18)∂L∂u1∗=A1u1∗+(λ2-λ3)γVHVUHU+(λ5-λ6)γVHVLHL-w11+w12=0 (19)∂L∂u2∗=A2u2∗-λ1γVIU-λ4γVIL-w21+w22=0.These imply that(20)u1∗=(λ3-λ2)γVHVUHU+(λ6-λ5)γVHVLHL+w11-w12A1 (21)u2∗=λ1γVIU+λ4γVIL+w21-w22A2.To obtain the explicit expressions of the optimal control without penalty terms we consider three sub-cases.i.
In the set {t:0<u1∗<1}, since by definition w11u1∗=w12(1-u1∗)=0, then w11=w12=0. As a result,(22)u1∗=(λ3-λ2)γVHVUHU+(λ6-λ5)γVHVLHLA1. ii.
In the set {t:u1∗=1}, we have w11=0 (since w11u1∗=w11=0) and(23)1=u1∗=(λ3-λ2)γVHVUHU+(λ6-λ5)γVHVLHL-w12A1 (24)⩽(λ3-λ2)γVHVUHU+(λ6-λ5)γVHVLHLA1(sincew12>0). iii.
In the set {t:u1∗=0}, we have w12=0 and(25)0=u1∗=(λ3-λ2)γVHVUHU+(λ6-λ5)γVHVLHL+w11A1 ⩾(λ3-λ2)γVHVUHU+(λ6-λ5)γVHVLHLA1sincew11>0.
In all the cases we have(26)u1∗=max0,min1,(λ3-λ2)γVHVUHU+(λ6-λ5)γVHVLHLA1.Likewise,i.
In the set {t:0<u2∗<1} we have w21=w22=0 and(27)u2∗=λ1γVIU+λ4γVILA2. ii.
In the set {t:u2=1},w21=0 and(28)1=u2∗=λ1γVIU+λ4γVIL-w22A2⩽λ1γVIU+λ4γVILA2. iii.
In the set {t:u2∗=0},w22=0 and(29)0=u2∗=λ1γVIU+λ4γVIL+w21A2⩾λ1γVIU+λ4γVILA2.
Hence we get(30)u2∗=max0,min1,λ1γVIU+λ4γVILA2.
□
By hypothesis, the optimal control is Lebesgue-measurable. We will show a stronger property, which is the continuity by using the optimality system.

sec.title: Continuity of the optimal control
sec.p:
The optimality system plays a crucial role in understanding the behaviour of the state system when the control is applied. It is composed of the state system (1), (7), adjoint system and the optimal control (u1∗,u2∗). In our case, the adjoint system is given by(31)dRdt=-∇xL,that is,(32)∂λ1∂t,…,∂λ7∂t=-∂L∂VU,∂L∂HU,∂L∂IU,∂L∂VL,∂L∂HL,∂L∂IL,∂L∂F,with the transversality conditions(33)λi(T)=0,i=1,2,…,7,where(34)∂L∂VU=a2-λ1γVHHU-λ2γHV(1-u1)HU+λ3γHV(1-u1)HU-λ1(αVH+aVH)∂L∂HU=-λ1γVHVU-2λ2bHDHU-λ2γHV(1-u1)VU-λ2aHFF+λ3γHV(1-u1)VU+λ2bHD(Hmax-IU)∂L∂IU=a1+λ1γV(1-u2)+λ2bHDHU-λ3aI-λ3aIFF∂L∂VL=a4+λ1β-λ4γVHHL-λ4αVH-λ4aVH-λ4β+λ6γVH(1-u1)HL-λ5γHV(1-u1)HL ∂L∂HL=-λ4γVHVL-2λ5bHDHL-λ5γHV(1-u1)VL-λ5aHFF-λ6γHV(1-u1)VL+λ5bHD(Hmax-IL)∂L∂IL=a3-λ4γV(1-u2)-λ5bHDHL-λ6aIFF-λ6aI+λ7bFI∂L∂F=-λ2aHFHU-λ3aIFIU-λ5aHFHL-λ6aIFIL-λ7aF. Proposition 3
An optimal control (u1∗,u2∗) for the control problem (11) is continuous.Proof
We note that(35)dRdt=-∇xL, =r1q1-q10000γVHVUr2-q20000-α1-bHDHUr30000-β00r4q4-q50000γVHVLr5q60000α1bHDHLr6-bFI0aHFHUaIFIU0aHFHLaIFILaFR(t)-a20a1a40a30,where r1=γVHHU+αVH+aVH,r2=2bHDHU+γVH(1-u1)VU+aHFF-bHD(Hmax-IU),r3=aI+aIFF r4=αVH+aVH+β+γVHHL,r5=2bHDHL+γHV(1-u1)VL+aHFF-bHD(Hmax-IL),r6=aI+aIFF,α1=(1-u2)γV,q1=γVH(1-u1)HU,q2=γHV(1-u1)VU,q3=γVH(1-u1)VL,q4=γHV(1-u1)HL,q5=γVH(1-u1)HL,q6=γHV(1-u1)VL. Since the Lagrangian in (14) is in the form(36)L=12(A1u12+A2u22)+lineartermsinu1oru2+termswithoutu1andu2,it is a quadratic function in the control. It is even a parabola since its coefficients do not depend on the control. Hence L is convex in the control, and by Pontragin’s Maximum Principle we have(37)L(t,u1,u2)⩽L(t,u1∗,u2∗)for almost all t∈[0,T] and for all u=(u1,u2)∈U. As a result, by Fleming and Rishel’s results [9], the optimal control (u1∗,u2∗) is continuous. □

sec.title: Uniqueness of the optimal control
sec.p:
We show in this section the uniqueness of the solution to the optimality system over small time intervals.Theorem 4
The solution of the optimality system is unique for t sufficiently small.Proof
Consider two solutions (x,u,λ) and (x¯,u¯,λ¯) of the optimality system, with x=(VU,HU,IU,VL,HL,IL,F),u=(u1,u2),λ=(λ1,λ2,λ3,λ4,λ5,λ6,λ7),x¯=(V¯U,H¯U,I¯U,V¯L,H¯L,I¯L,F¯),u¯=(u¯1,u¯2) and λ¯=(λ¯1,λ¯2,λ¯3,λ¯4,λ¯5,λ¯6,λ¯7). We let(38)VU=eαtP1,HU=eαtP2,IU=eαtP3,VL=eαtP4,HL=eαtP5,IL=eαtP6,F=eαtP7,λ1=e-αtr1,λ2=e-αtr2,λ3=e-αtr3,λ4=e-αtr4,λ5=e-αtr5,λ6=e-αtr6,λ7=e-αtr7,V¯U=eαtP¯1,H¯U=eαtP¯2,I¯U=eαtP¯3,V¯L=eαtP¯4,H¯L=eαtP¯5,I¯L=eαtP¯6, F¯=eαtP¯7,λ¯1=e-αtr¯1,λ¯2=e-αtr¯2,λ¯3=e-αtr¯3,λ¯4=e-αtr¯4,λ¯5=e-αtr¯5,λ¯6=e-αtr¯6,λ¯7=e-αtr¯7.Then(39)u1=max0,min1,(eαtγVH[(r3-r2)P3P2+(r6-r5)P4P5]A1 (40)u2=max0,min1,γV(r1P3+r4P6A2.Likewise,(41)u¯1=max0,min1,(eαtγVH[(r¯3-r¯2)P¯3P¯2+(r¯6-r¯5)P¯4P¯5]A1 (42)u¯2=max0,min1,γV(r¯1P¯3+r¯4P¯6A2.Substituting (38) in the state system (1), (7) and the adjoint system (32), we obtain(43)dP1dt+αP1=(1-u1)γVP3-γVHeαtP1P2-(αVH+aVH)P1+βP4 (44)dP2dt+αP2=bHD(Hmax-eαtP2-eαtP3)P2-(1-u1)γHVeαtP1P2-aHVeαtP2P7 (45)dP3dt+αP3=(1-u1)γHVeαtP1P2-aIFeαtP3P7-aIP3 (46)dP4dt+αP4=(1-u2)γVP6-γHVeαtP4P5+(-αVH-aVH-β)P4 (47)dP5dt+αP5=bHD(Hmax-eαt(P5-P6)P5-(1-u1)γHVeαtP4P5-aHFeαtP7P5 (48)dP6dt+αP6=(1-u1)γHVeαtP4P5-aIFeαtP7P6-aIP6 (49)dP7dt+αP7=bFI(P3+P6)-aFP7 (50)dr1dt-αr1=-a2eαt-γVHeαtr1P2+(1-u1)γHVeαtP4r2-(1-u1)γHVeαtr3 (51)dr2dt-αr2=γVHeαtr2P1-r2bHDeαtP2+(1-u1)γVHeαtr2P1-aHFe2αtP7+(1-u1)γHVeαtr3P1 (52)dr3dt-αr3=-a1eαt-(1-u2)γVr1-r2bHDeαtP2+aIr3 (53)dr4dt-αr4=-a4eαt-r1β+r4γVHeαtP5+r4(αVH+aVH+β)-r6(1-u1)γVHeαtP5 (54)dr5dt-αr5=r4γVHeαtP4+2r5bHDeαtP5+(1-u1)γHVeαtr5P4+r5aHFe2αtP7+r6γHVeαtP4 (55)dr6dt-αr6=-a3eαt+(1-u2)γVr4+r5bHDeαtP5+r6aIFe2αtP7+r6aI-r7bFI (56)dr7dt-αr7=r2aHFe2αtP2+r3aIFe2αtP3+r5aHFe2αtP5+r6aIFe2αtP6-r7aF.In the same manner we get(57)dP¯1dt+αP¯1=(1-u¯1)γVP¯3-γVHeαtP¯1P¯2-(αVH+aVH)P¯1+βP¯4 (58)dP¯2dt+αP¯2=bHD(Hmax-eαtP¯2-eαtP¯3)P¯2-(1-u¯1)γHVeαtP¯1P¯2-aHVeαtP¯2P¯7 (59)dP¯3dt+αP¯3=(1-u¯1)γHVeαtP¯1P¯2-aIFeαtP¯3P¯7-aIP¯3 (60)dP¯4dt+αP¯4=(1-u¯2)γVP¯6-γHVeαtP¯4P¯5+(-αVH-aVH-β)P¯4 (61)dP¯5dt+αP¯5=bHD(Hmax-eαt(P¯5-P¯6)P¯5-(1-u¯1)γHVeαtP¯4P¯5-aHFeαtP¯7P¯5 (62)dP¯6dt+αP¯6=(1-u¯1)γHVeαtP¯4P¯5-aIFeαtP¯7P¯6-aIP¯6 (63)dP¯7dt+αP¯7=bFI(P¯3+P¯6)-aFP¯7 (64)dr¯1dt-αr¯1=-a2eαt-γVHeαtr¯1P¯2+(1-u¯1)γHVeαtP¯4r¯2-(1-u¯1)γHVeαtr¯3 (65)dr¯2dt-αr¯2=γVHeαtr¯2P¯1-r¯2bHDeαtP¯2+(1-u¯1)γVHeαtr¯2P¯1-aHFe2αtP¯7+(1-u¯1)γHVeαtr¯3P¯1 (66)dr¯3dt-αr¯3=-a1eαt-(1-u¯2)γVr¯1-r¯2bHDeαtP¯2+aIr¯3 (67)dr¯4dt-αr¯4=-a4eαt-r¯1β+r¯4γVHeαtP¯5+r¯4(αVH+aVH+β)-r¯6(1-u¯1)γVHeαtP¯5 (68)dr¯5dt-αr¯5=r¯4γVHeαtP¯4+2r¯5bHDeαtP¯5+(1-u¯1)γHVeαtr¯5P¯4+r¯5aHFe2αtP¯7+r¯6γHVeαtP¯4 (69)dr¯6dt-αr¯6=-a3eαt+(1-u¯2)γVr¯4+r¯5bHDeαtP¯5+r¯6aIFe2αtP¯7+r¯6aI-r¯7bFI (70)dr¯7dt-αr¯7=r¯2aHFe2αtP¯2+r¯3aIFe2αtP¯3+r¯5aHFe2αtP¯5+r¯6aIFe2αtP¯6-r¯7aF.Subtracting (57) from (43), we get(71)(dP1dt-dP¯1dt)+α(P1-P¯1)=γV(1-u1)P3-γV(1-u¯1)P¯3-γVHeαt(P1P2-P¯1P¯2)-(αVH+aVH)(P1-P¯1)+β(P4-P¯4).Multiplying (71) by (P1-P‾1) then integrating over [0,T], we get(72)12[P1(T)-P¯1(T)]2+α∫0T(P1-P¯1)2dt=+β∫0Teαt(P1-P¯1)(P4-P¯4)dt-γVH∫0Teαt(P1P2-P1¯P2¯)(P1-P¯1)dt-(αVH+aVH)∫0T(P1-P¯1)2dt+γv∫0T[(1-u1)P3-(1-u¯1)P¯3](P1-P¯1)dt.Substituting u1,u2,u¯1 and u¯2 by their values in (72), then simplifying, we arrive at(73)12[P1(T)-P¯1(T)]2+α∫0T(P1-P¯1)2dt⩽C1∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P3-P¯3)2]dt+C2eαT∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P6-P¯6)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r6-r¯6)2+(r5-r¯5)2]dt+C3∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P4-P¯4)2]dt.In the same manner, we obtain(74)12[P2(T)-P¯2(T)]2+α∫0T(P2-P¯2)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T[(P2-P¯2)2+(P3-P¯3)2]dt+C2eαT∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2]dt+C3eαT∫0T[(P2-P¯2)2+(P6-P¯6)2]dt, (75)12[P3(T)-P¯3(T)]2+α∫0T(P3-P¯3)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2]dt+C2eαT∫0T[(P3-P¯3)2+(P6-P¯6)2]dt+aI∫0T(P3-P¯3)2dt, (76)12[P4(T)-P¯4(T)]2+α∫0T(P4-P¯4)2dt⩽C1∫0T[(P3-P¯3)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P6-P¯6)2+(r1-r¯1)2+(r4-r¯4)2]dt+C2∫0T[(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2]dt+C3∫0T(P4-P¯4)2dt, (77)12[P5(T)-P¯5(T)]2+α∫0T(P5-P¯5)2dt⩽C1eαt∫0T[(P5-P¯5)2+(P6-P¯6)2]dt+C2eαT∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2]dt+C3eαT∫0T[(P5-P¯5)2+(P7-P¯7)2]dt (78)12[P6(T)-P¯6(T)]2+α∫0T(P6-P¯6)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(P6-P¯6)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2]dt+C2eαT∫0T[(P6-P¯6)2+(P7-P¯7)2]dt+aI∫0T(P6-P¯6)2dt (79)12[P7(T)-P¯7(T)]2+α∫0T(P7-P¯7)2dt⩽bFI∫0T[(P3-P¯3)2+(P6-P¯6)2+(P7-P¯7)2]dt+aF∫0T(P7-7¯3)2dt (80)12[r1(T)-r¯1(T)]2-α∫0T(r1-r¯1)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T[(r1-r¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2]dt+C2eαT∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r1-r¯1)2]dt+C3eαT∫0T[(r1-r¯1)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2+(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2]dt, (81)12[r2(T)-r¯2(T)]2-α∫0T(r2-r¯2)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T[(r2-r¯2)2+(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2]dt+C2eαT∫0T[(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2+(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2]dt+C3eαT∫0T[(r2-r¯2)2+(P7-P¯7)2]dt, (82)12[r3(T)-r¯3(T)]2-α∫0T(r3-r¯3)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T[(r1-r¯1)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r4-r¯4)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P6-P¯6)2]dt+C2eαT∫0T[(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r4-r¯4)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P6-P¯6)2]dt+C3eαT∫0T(r3-r¯3)2dt, (83)12[r4(T)-r¯4(T)]2-α∫0T(r4-r¯4)2dt⩽β∫0T[(r1-r¯1)2+(r4-r¯4)2]dt+C1eαT∫0T[(r4-r¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2]dt+C1eαT∫0T[(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r4-r¯4)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2+(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2]dt, (84)12[r5(T)-r¯5(T)]2-α∫0T(r5-r¯5)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T(r4-r¯4)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(P4-P¯4)2dt+C2eαT∫0T(r5-r¯5)2+(P5-P¯5)2dt+C3eαT∫0T(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2+(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2dt+C4eαT∫0T(r5-r¯5)2+(P7-P¯7)2dt, (85)12[r6(T)-r¯6(T)]2-α∫0T(r6-r¯6)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T(r1-r¯1)2+(r4-r¯4)2+(r6-r¯6)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P6-P¯6)2dt+C2eαT∫0T(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯6)2+(P5-P¯5)2dt+C3eαT∫0T(r6-r¯6)2+(P7-P¯7)2dt+aI∫0T(r6-r¯6)2dt, (86)12[r7(T)-r¯7(T)]2-α∫0T(r7-r¯7)2dt⩽C1eαT∫0T(r2-r¯2)2+(r7-r¯7)2+(P2-P¯2)2dt+C2eαT∫0T(r3-r¯3)2+(r7-r¯7)2+(P6-P¯6)2dt+aF∫0T(r7-r¯7)2dt.Adding (73), (86), we obtain the following estimation(87)α0+α∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(P6-P¯6)2+(P7-P¯7)2]dt-α∫0T[(r1-r¯1)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r4-r¯4)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯)2+(r7-r¯7)2]dt⩽C2e4αT∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(P6-P¯6)2+(P7-P¯7)2+(r1-r¯1)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r4-r¯4)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯)2+(r7-r¯7)2]dt+C1∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(P6-P¯6)2+(P7-P¯7)2+(r1-r¯1)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r4-r¯4)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯)2+(r7-r¯7)2]dt,where(88)α0=12[P1(T)-P¯1(T)]2+12[P2(T)-P¯2(T)]2+12[P3(T)-P¯3(T)]2+12[P4(T)-P¯4(T)]2+12[P5(T)-P¯5(T)]2+12[P6(T)-P¯6(T)]2+12[P7(T)-P¯7(T)]2+12[r1(T)-r¯1(T)]2+12[r2(T)-r¯2(T)]2+12[r3(T)-r¯3(T)]2+12[r4(T)-r¯4(T)]2+12[r5(T)-r¯5(T)]2+12[r6(T)-r¯6(T)]2+12[r7(T)-r¯7(T)]2.This implies that(89)α0+(α-C2e4αt-C1)∫0T[(P1-P¯1)2+(P2-P¯2)2+(P3-P¯3)2+(P4-P¯4)2+(P5-P¯5)2+(P6-P¯6)2+(P7-P¯7)2+(r1-r¯1)2+(r2-r¯2)2+(r3-r¯3)2+(r4-r¯4)2+(r5-r¯5)2+(r6-r¯)2+(r7-r¯7)2]dt⩽0for α⩾C2e4αt+C1, that is, t⩽T=14αlogα-C1C2. As a result, x(t)=x¯(t) and λ(t)=λ¯(t) for all t∈[0,T]. Hence the solution of the optimality system is unique. □

sec.title: Numerical simulations
sec.p: We plot the solution under different control scenarios using the experimental data from Mochan [17]: γV=3459×106,γVH=3.179,αVH=0.3077,β=0.0540,Hmax=50,γHV=0.00000076,aHF=0.0099,aIF=0.0126,aI=4.498,αVL=0.0014,aVH=6.062,bHD=43910,bFI=0.0078,aF=10.250,aVL=431.59,aG=0.0835,γFG=0.1179 et aHL=40, and the initial conditions VU(0)=10,HU(0)=700,IU(0)=20,VL(0)=10,HL(0)=400,IL(0)=5,F(0)=100,G(0)=100.

When there is no therapy to inhibit viral production, we observe in Fig. 1 that therapy for preventing new infections can overturn the state of infection only if it is highly effective (at least 99%). A similar observation is made in Fig. 2 in the absence of therapy to prevent new infections. Although infected epithelial cells foster the production of virions, we observe (in Fig. 3, Fig. 4, Fig. 5 ) that inhibiting viral production is more effective than preventing new infections.Fig. 1
Distribution of virions when there is no drug therapy to inhibit viral production.Fig. 2
Distribution of virions when there is no drug therapy to prevent new infections.Fig. 3
Distribution of virions when using drug therapy to prevent new infections and inhibit viral production are highly effective.Fig. 4
Distribution of infected epithelial cells when drug efficacy is either not or 100% effective.Fig. 5
Distribution of infected epithelial cells when drug efficacy is highly effective.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this work, we analysed a mathematical virus model for Covid-19. Unlike previous approaches, the model considers the inflammatory response to viral infection, using information from pro-inflammatory mediators to combat viral growth. It also captures the dynamics in the lower and upper respiratory tracts. The sensibility analysis revealed that reducing the infection rate of epithelial cells or the replication rate of the virus was the best strategy to limit secondary infections. Their implementation requires cost. We introduced two control parameters to prevent cell infections and inhibit viral production. Then we considered an optimal control problem aimed at minimizing cell infections and virions proliferation at minimal cost. We fully analyzed the control problem and established the existence and uniqueness of its solution. We also characterized and established the continuity of the optimal control. Numerical simulations depicted the contribution of the control parameters in the infection dynamics. They can significantly hamper and even stop the production rate of virions provided that the drug therapy is highly effective (see Fig. 1, Fig. 2).

This work presents a quantitative tool for the impact of drug therapy on infection dynamics. It also highlights the necessity of not only manufacturing drugs, but they should be highly effective to have a significant impact. For future work, we will consider fractional order derivatives as they are proved to capture more information, and will design numerical methods. Unlike previous approaches [Arshad et al.[1], Baleanu et al. [5], Kumar et al. [15]], we will consider the virus model to understand the dynamics within the body.
